s.text: Today's Papers' only complaint about Broad's re-look is that it somewhat unfairly chips away at the impression the paper had originally created: The three-page piece waits until the second-to-last column to state that the consensus of the American intelligence agencies is that espionage played a role in China's catch-up even if there is no smoking-gun evidence for this.
The paper's coverage has generally been clear in attributing the Wen Ho Lee-probably-did-it line to particular (named and unnamed) government sources.
Or worse, some sort of illegitimate attempt by the paper to revise its history of coverage on the subject?
